section.title: Introduction
section.para: Beacon is a WYSIWYM based XML editor with an emphasis on clean and sane output. It uses a 'fill in the blanks' approach to web- based editing and has a plug-in architecture to allow other documentation types to be integrated as well.
Currently Beacon is under development but the source can be obtained from our GIT repository.

We try our best to make sure that the tree does not have broken code! A beta release is not far though. For a more detailed installation guide please have a look at https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/DocBook_Editor_Documentation.

section.title: Getting Started
section.para: Once you are setup and ready to go, point your browser to the Beacon setup and let it load.

note.title: Reduce Loading Times
note.para: You can reduce loading time by loading less number of plug-ins.

section.para: When Beacon loads you can see a basic introduction page with a sidebar on the right. This will be the usual structure of all document workspaces that you will create in Beacon.

listitem.para: A Sidebar - Has a lot of tools like trees and insert options.
Main Content - Shows the document itself and some options on top along with last saved information.

section.para: Beacon has a very simple UI. In the next section we'll describe how to edit a document. When you create a new document it opens in a new tab. You can navigate between different tabs and work on multiple documents simultaneously.

section.title: Editing a Document
section.para: Clicking anywhere on the main document will cause an editor to open up if the node that you have clicked allows editing. While editing, click anywhere else on the document except the node you are editing to close the editor. You can alternatively hit the return key to close the inline editor.

itemizedlist.title: The top bar above the main content has:

listitem.para: Save Button: Saves the document to the server.

XML View Button: This removes the design view and shows the raw XML. This can also be edited and the changes will reflect back to design view. To get back to the design view hit the XML view button again.
Last saved information: This label shows when the document was last saved.

section.para: The side bar has two blocks in an accordion widget. Clicking on one collapses the other. The default open view shows a document tree. The document tree shows all nodes in the document. One can focus the design view on a particular node by double clicking that node in the tree.

itemizedlist.title: Right clicking a node brings up a context menu with the following options:

section.para: The first and second options are used to create new nodes in the document. When clicked a tree node will appear with a drop down select box. This select box will contain the list of node that can be added here. Choose one and you will see it appear in the design view.

Below the Document Tree there is a block called ëInsert Inline Childí. This is used to insert inline nodes on selected text in the document. Select a piece of text when using a rich text editor (say on a paragraph, usually headings do not allow it) and move to the select box to choose inline type. Select one and click Insert. This will cause the highlighted text to be wrapped with that particular inline type.

note.title: Populating Lists
note.para: To maintain the sanity of the document, only those child and sibling nodes are shown which are allowed by the DocBook DTD for that node.
